比爾蓋茲對「全球健康」的未來發展，做出充滿希望的預言
07 Nov 2019, 08:00 by TIME
文：RACHAEL BUNYAN譯：劉松宏
比爾．蓋茲（Bill Gates）週一（10月7日）在劍橋大學對一位觀眾說道，如果世界各國領導人均選擇資助科學創新，那麼到了2040年，全球營養不足的問題將會得以解決，瘧疾也幾乎會完全消除。
這位微軟聯合創始人在英格蘭劍橋聯合學會（Cambridge Union）發表談話時提道：「我很幸運，我的工作讓我能看到目前所有令人驚奇的種種發現，這就是為什麼我能夠預測未來。」
蓋茲被提名為2019年霍金教授獎學金的獲獎者，該獎學金由劍橋大學聯合學會於2017年設立，以紀念史蒂芬．霍金對該所大學的貢獻。
蓋茲引用了史蒂芬．霍金最後一本著作《霍金大見解：留給世人的十個大哉問與解答》中的一個問題，並且詢問所有觀眾：「我們要如何塑造未來？」
這位億萬富翁慈善家正試圖透過解決「比爾和梅琳達．蓋茲基金會」（Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation）的全球健康問題和不平等現象來塑造未來。蓋茲於週一時預言：科學家將會解決營養不足的問題，並在未來20年內全球與營養相關的死亡人數也將大幅減少。蓋茲說道：「透過解決營養不足的問題，我們將得以解決造成不平等現象的最大因素之一。」
根據世界衛生組織（WHO）的資料，營養不足約占了5歲以下兒童死亡人數的一半左右。
蓋茲指出近年來科學家研發解決方案的方式，包含了添加維生素和礦物質的強化食品或補給品、用於傳染病的疫苗和藥物，以及改善產婦健康。
但是蓋茲表示解決營養不良的另一項關鍵因素，是要了解細菌所扮演的角色。蓋茲補充道，在健康的身體中，「益菌」可以保護我們免於遭受感染，並且對消化功能至關重要──如果你體內的細菌沒有達到標準，很可能會導致嚴重的營養不良。
在過去數年中，科學家們在理解「腸道因微生物群或細菌異常而作用低下」以及「如何改變腸道菌叢（包括益生菌的發展）」方面取得了突破。蓋茲認為透過更多的創新和研究，科學家將能夠藉由製造「含有理想細菌組合──甚至能針對特定腸道量身打造──的益生菌藥丸」，在未來20年內解決營養不足的問題。
蓋茲說道：「如果我們能夠搞清楚營養狀況──我相信將在未來20年內有望達成──就能拯救數百萬人的生命，並更進一步改善生活。」
根據蓋茲表示，解決營養不良和其他疾病將代表著一種轉變：不僅僅是拯救生命，更是改善我們的生活。他說道：「這似乎只是一點細微的差異，但這將大大影響你使用醫療保健的形式。在20年之內，我相信地球上的每個國家都將不僅能專注於讓人民存活，更可以讓人民維持健康。」
蓋茲更談到了瘧疾，也是該基金會特別關注的重要領域。瘧疾每年造成全世界43萬5000人死亡。蓋茲預測到了2040年，瘧疾將幾乎被消滅，但單靠藥物還不足以實現這一目標。他說道：「遏止瘧疾的關鍵是控制傳染媒介──而以瘧疾來說，傳染媒介就是蚊子。」
對於蓋茨而言，一種潛在的解決方案在於基因編輯，這項技術使得科學家們可以單獨對付那些攜帶瘧疾病源的蚊子。他說道：「插入一段阻止這些壞蚊子繼續繁殖的基因，將使我們更有時間治癒瘧疾地區的所有人。接著，我們可以讓蚊子族群在沒有寄生蟲的情況下回歸。」
蓋茲表示對衛生創新進行投資，是改善全球衛生、縮小衛生不平等之間的差距，以及減少全球貧窮的關鍵。
「世界正處於改善全球健康的關鍵時刻……各國目前正在決定這些投資是否值得進行。」蓋茲繼續說道：「未來是由我們創造的──如果我們選擇將創新放在第一位的話。改善健康狀況對於讓人們脫離貧窮來說就非常重要。當改善了健康狀況，人們的生產力也會提高。」
「當更多的兒童能夠存活到成年，家庭就會決定減少生子數量，這可能會導致經濟成長大爆發。」

text:
Bill Gates makes a promising prediction about the future development of "global health"
07 Nov 2019, 08:00 by TIME
Text: RACHAEL BUNYAN translation: Liu Songhong
Bill. Bill Gates told an audience at Cambridge University on Monday (October 7th) that if world leaders choose to fund scientific innovation, then by 2040, global malnutrition will be solved, and malaria will be It will almost completely disappear.
The Microsoft co-founder said in a conversation at the Cambridge Union in England: "I am very fortunate that my work allows me to see all the amazing discoveries, which is why I can predict the future. ."
Gates was nominated for the winner of the 2019 Professor Hawking Scholarship, which was established in 2017 by the Cambridge University Joint Society to commemorate Stephen. Hawking's contribution to the university.
Gates quoted Steven. One of the questions in Hawking’s last book, Hawking’s Insights: Ten Questions and Answers for the World, and asked all the audience: “How do we shape the future?”
The billionaire philanthropist is trying to shape the future by addressing the global health problems and inequalities of the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation. Gates predicted on Monday that scientists will address the problem of undernutrition and that the number of global nutrition-related deaths will also drop significantly over the next 20 years. Gates said: "By addressing the problem of undernutrition, we will be able to solve one of the biggest causes of inequality."
According to the World Health Organization (WHO), undernutrition accounts for about half of the death toll of children under five.
Gates pointed out that scientists have developed solutions in recent years, including fortified foods or supplements with vitamins and minerals, vaccines and drugs for infectious diseases, and improved maternal health.
But Gates said that another key factor in addressing malnutrition is to understand the role of bacteria. Gates adds that in a healthy body, "probiotics" protects us from infection and is essential for digestive function - if your body's bacteria are not up to standard, it can cause severe malnutrition.
In the past few years, scientists have made breakthroughs in understanding "the intestines are ineffective due to microbial or bacterial abnormalities" and "how to change the intestinal flora (including the development of probiotics)." Gates believes that through more innovation and research, scientists will be able to address undernutrition in the next 20 years by making "probiotic pills with ideal bacterial combinations that can be tailored to specific guts." problem.
Gates said: "If we can figure out the nutritional status -- which I believe will be achieved in the next 20 years -- it will save millions of lives and further improve their lives."
According to Gates, addressing malnutrition and other diseases will represent a shift: not only to save lives, but to improve our lives. He said: "This seems to be only a slight difference, but it will greatly affect your use of health care. Within 20 years, I believe that every country on the planet will not only focus on making people survive, but also Let the people stay healthy."
Gates talked about malaria and is an important area of special interest to the foundation. Malaria kills 435,000 people worldwide each year. Gates predicted that malaria will be almost wiped out in 2040, but drugs alone are not enough to achieve this goal. He said: "The key to curbing malaria is to control the vector - and in the case of malaria, the vector is a mosquito."
One of the potential solutions for Gates is gene editing, a technology that allows scientists to deal with mosquitoes that carry malaria. He said: "Insert a gene that prevents these bad mosquitoes from continuing to multiply, which will give us more time to cure everyone in the malaria area. Then we can let the mosquito population return without parasites."
Gates said that investing in health innovation is key to improving global health, reducing the gap between health inequalities, and reducing global poverty.
"The world is at a critical juncture to improve global health... Countries are currently deciding whether these investments are worthwhile." Gates continues: "The future is what we create - if we choose to put innovation first. Health is important to get people out of poverty. When health is improved, people's productivity will increase."
"When more children can survive to adulthood, the family will decide to reduce the number of children, which may lead to economic growth."
